review_blob: No head, Brownish/ dark amber. Malty with some dark fruits. Rather sessie/drinkable.
Smells, looks and has the initial taste of cider. Hints of root and oak. Reminds me of autumn.
Light and orangy color. Small white head with a mild hop-citrus aroma. Slight bite of hops and a flat citrus aftertaste. Not very balanced.

Thanks FrumptyDumpty. Nose of slight malts and hops. Nice medium-dark copper almost red color with a large head fading to about 2 fingers of tannish red head. Smooth and malty, quick bite of hops followed by oak and iron. Warm silky mouthfeel.

Great hop, citrus and skunky bud aroma with a copper and clear color. Bountiful creamy looking head from an aggro pour. Punchy citrus hop bite with a nice finish. Coppery with a decent balance, not a bad IPA. Good lacing and pronounced gulp rings. Better as it warms and has time to breathe. * Design note* What design? It looks like they got someone who "knows the computer" to design this in Word or something. Have respect for your own product.

(bottle - 750 ml) Nose: yeasty floral hop aroma. Appearance is a cloudy amber. The head is big, 2-3 in. and pillowy eventually fading. A smooth finish, taste is spicy and floral, very clean from the coriander. First contact with the tongue is slightly sour but leaves with the carbonation (theres lots of it) hints of the oak aging. Rather pleasant overall, ideal for a spring/summer afternoon. * Design note* The illustrated label does a more than adequate job of conveying the overall experience of this ale.

bottle. Malty nose Dark brown with a slight tan head. Very mild porter, roasty base malts, with a smokey finish. Possibly a sessie porter? Not bad. *Design note* Like most Averty products this brew has some fairly ugly packaging, just look at it over there. Does that say quality when you look at it? Obviously the packaging has no bearing on a rating but as a consumer if you had the choice between two brews you have never heard of, would this say "drink me"?

Bottle. Orange/ amber and clowdy. Moderate sized white head quickly dissipates. Nose of champage and yeast. Dry with a subtle taste of fruit (peaches, lemon, mandarine orange). Initial bite subsides as the carbonation quickly fades giving way to a wine like aftertaste, oak becoming more aparent as the bottle finishes.

Bottle, 2000 harvest. Dark amber and cloudy w/ light brown head disapearing to a few bubbles. Sweet malty aroma. Malty taste with tobacco and oak, slightly sweet. Nice smooth finish. High gravity with out being to boozy tasting. Not bad at all, goes right to the head, rather drinkable. *Designer note* I kind of like the packaging for this brew, a nice homey wood block illustration on natural colored label. Not flashy but stood off of the shelf  amidst some of the design disasters that exist in craft brew packaging.

Cloudy with a tangerine hue. Small head diminishing to nothing. mild floral aroma, some citrus. Mild citrus taste, decent balance of hops slightly maltier than i expected. Finishing with a slight bite and mandarin aftertaste. WARNING do not attempt to eat Indian food halfway through this beer, especially Aloo Choley, if you do this beer we taste like Ketchup. Im not quite sure how that works but it does, a real mood breaker.
Bottle. Nice looking with a tan head and a nice dark amber color. Caramel and malty with a warm alcohol finish. Not overwhelming but not bad either.
Bottle. A beautiful beer, wonderful coffee and chocolate taste with a smooth finish. Medium to full body. Great looking. I m a fan.

Hearty and intense like a barleywine, dark amber with white colored head. Great nose that instantly reminds me of the 90 minute. rather sweet and fruity. Overall i loved the first third but it was tough going from then on, dont let the IPA tag fool you, this dose pack a punch.
